elements.title:
The "Alpina" ski area has switched to a "dynamic" price model. The prices for the day passes change every day. The basic price for the day pass is CHF 50. Let's take a closer look at the respective reasons for price changes on four ski days.
On day 1, the snow conditions are optimal and the weather is very good. 
On day 2 it is raining. 
Day 3 is a Sunday.
Day 4 is just before the end of the season. The two neighboring ski areas, which are similar in size, have already closed.

elements.name: Entscheiden Sie, ob die jeweilige Ursache primär die Angebots- oder die Nachfrageseite betrifft.
elements.title: Decide whether the cause primarily affects the supply side or the demand side.

elements.name: panel1
elements.title: The "Alpina" ski area has fewer customers this year than last year because there is often no snow at all. Almost all other ski resorts in the region are experiencing the same situation. Many ski resorts are therefore trying to attract customers with low prices for day tickets.

elements.name: question3
elements.title: What does this development mean for the number of ski resorts in this region in the long term? Formulate an assumption based on a market law. Make a note of the market law as well as the assumption.
elements.correctAnswer: The number of ski resorts will fall in the long term = market law 4: prices fall = supply falls

elements.name: panel2
elements.title: The "Alpina" ski resort also has problems with the strong Swiss franc.

elements.name: question5
elements.title: Write down the technical term for the exchange price of currencies such as CHF, euros or dollars and the name of the market on which currencies are exchanged.

elements.name: question6
elements.title: Note the market law that is responsible for the CHF strengthening.
elements.correctAnswer: Market law 2: Demand > supply = prices rise

elements.name: question7
elements.title: Explain to a colleague why the strong CHF is a problem for the "Alpina" ski resort.
elements.correctAnswer: A strong CHF makes Swiss products and services (such as day tickets for a ski resort) more expensive for foreign guests. As a result, their demand decreases and the turnover of ski resorts falls.
